snippet: New research suggests that prunelike wrinkles on fingers and toes may have evolved to give early humans an advantage in wet conditions.
abstract: Study in journal Biology Letters suggests that wrinkled fingers and toes resulting from prolonged submersion in water may have evolved to allow better grip in wet conditions.
lead_paragraph: New research suggests that prunelike wrinkles on fingers and toes may have evolved to give early humans an advantage in wet conditions.

headline.seo: Wrinkled Fingers Get Better Grip on Wet Objects
headline.main: Wet Wrinkled Fingers Evolved for Better Grip
headline.print_headline: Wet Wrinkled Fingers Evolved for Better Grip
